messages: f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:08): What happened to the peer-to-peer communication spec?
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:08): is there still one
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:08): some parts of the communication stuff got moved to websocket spec
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:09): and some to postmessage
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:09): but where did the peer-to-peer part go
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:09): more specifically, how do I code a clientside websocket server in javascript
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:10): it didn't go anywhere
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:10): it's simply not done
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:11): but are the place holders still somewhere?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:11): sure
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:11): I cannot find them
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:11): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete/commands.html#peer-to-peer-connections
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:13): I'm thinking that maybe letting javascript listen on an IPv4 interface is not a good idea
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:13): but some discardable virtual addresses might work
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:14): I'm trying to research that kind of approaches as part of my work
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:14): and I am just wondering, if others have similar ideas
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:15): the WHATWG email archives have some additional information
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:15): other than that I think it is ok
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:15): I mean, not much
f38a4efb547c845a4350043200ddc4d7 (19:16): in my opinion browser-to-browser communication should be IPv4, but the actual js-to-js communication should probably use some new addressing model
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (19:16): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Aren't you supposed to out partying on the streets or something
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:19): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, already did
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:20): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, but I'll be out again soon :)
58869a2e5c3f0eab9aa398b0a798e354 (19:20): It was quite an unexpected win.. I didn't give our team a very big chance.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (19:20): I'm trying to tweet #worldcup #ned #win but it's not responding
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:36): re: CSS on captions: A plain text-shadow with a small blur is enough to render captions readable on any background.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:36): You don't need to stack 9 atop each other, just do something like "color:white;text-shadow:0 0 .2em black;"
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:38): At least, that works for my gradient-demonstration page that I made a long time ago, and keeps the text visible on any gradient I've ever done.
cdbe0e8aea85495cfcf22db2db988e7d (19:40): http://www.joindiaspora.com//2010/07/01/one-month-in.html

cdbe0e8aea85495cfcf22db2db988e7d (19:41): "We have also started to build the latest and greatest in web standards into Diaspora. Websockets are already in the Diaspora core, and any Diaspora plugins will be able to have rapid two-way functionality, (think chat, games etc) almost effortlessly!"
7cbd522d7fcf593a1e60d52c789b6a7b (19:41): thats awesome
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:45): Too bad WebSockets aren't remotely stable yet?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:46): uses websockets + heaps of other companies
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:46): the spec may not be stable, but the technology seems it
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:48): Chrome's implementation just changed completely incompatibly in the dev channel, didn't it?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:48): Chromium is currently draft 76+, chrome is 75
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:48): if, that's what you mean
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (19:49): Yeah, 75-76 has some breaking changes, iirc.
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:49): but there's been no other changes since, right?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:50): Since like a month or two ago, no.
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:50): I'm on top of the spec then
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (19:50): But more incompatible changes are likely, from what I've heard.
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:53): I hope they don't go with that SSL type thing that was being concocted
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (19:53): that'd be really bad for the protocol, imho.
